Environmental factors, such as heat stress, drought and nutrients, influence plant morphology, physiology and chemistry, resulting in bottom-up effects on insect herbivore survival and performance
9â€“ 13 . Water-deficit as single stressor may influence aphids indirectly through changes in plant physiology, including an increase in nitrogen levels due to the inhibition of protein metabolism and amino acid synthesis
4, 14 . The increase in phloem nitrogen, which consists largely of free amino acids, may benefit the growth and reproduction of phloem-feeding insects such as aphids
15 . However, reduced turgor pressure and water content may render access to increased plant nitrogen more difficult and thus negatively affect phloem-feeding insects on water-stressed plants
